div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,412] ALEXANDRIA, Tuesday, FEBRUARY 6, 1906. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Office of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, Every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindiel Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined sea and special train fare os 22.9.11 Port said to london via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent. on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London calling Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every altenate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.

row.cell: F.G. Davidson Superintandent P & O S.N Company in Egypt

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Orontes" will leave Suez about February 9
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about February 23.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ormuz" will leave Port Said February 12
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Port Said February 26
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 0/0 if return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON. Departures from Suez.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, leaves about February 15.
S.S. Warwickshire 7,966 tons, leaves about March 1.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Herefordshire 7,182 tons, leaves about February 5.
S.S. Shropshire 5,785 tons leaves about February 19.
FARES from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0, London £17.0.0, Colombo £32.10.0, Rangoon £37.10.0.
Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Tabor now on the berth, will sail on or about Wednesday, February 14, to be followed by S.S. Rameses.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

S.S. IRRAWADDY 7300 Tons will leave PORT SAID about February 20 for Liverpool.
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about March 11 for Malta, Gibraltar &Devonport
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.

NILE STEAMER SERVICES
TOURIST SERVICE - The large and splendidly appointed S.S. "Rameses the Great" will leave Cairo on Tuesday, February 13th for Luxor, Assuan and Philae.
ASSIUT SERVICE - First-class Tourist Steamers Amasis or Tewfik will leave Assiut every Tuesday for Luxor, Assuan and Philae. 14 days on the Nile including excursions for £35.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
EXPRESS SERVICE - Steamers leave Cairo every Monday and Friday for Luxor, Assuan and Philae. 19 days on the Nile for £22.

Special combined rail and steamer Nile Tours at greatly reduced fares. Bi Weekly Service to Halfa, Khartoum and the Sudan. Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties. Regular service of freight steamers between Cairo &Halfa. Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principal Railway Stations and landing places in Europe to assit passengers holding their tickets. Tours to Palestine, Syria, and Desert. Best Equipment. Lowest charges.

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about17&31 January,February 14&28at 4 p.m.
Syrian. Caramanian Line
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about22 January,5&19 February4 p.m.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about29 January,12&26 February,4 p.m.
Far East Lines

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about February 3 and March 6 and April 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about February 9 and March 9. To Djibouti, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about January 20and February 20.
East African Line.
Departures from Suez: To Aden, Mombassa, Zanzibar, Beira, Delagoa Bay, Durban, about Febr. 3 and March 6andApril 3.
For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Port Said and Suez, Thos. Cook & Son, Ld., Leon Heller, Cairo Agent, 4, Sharia Maghraby, (Telephone 192), Cairo; F. Tedeschi, Helouan.

TRANSPORT DEPARTMENT. Six days White Nile Tourist Trip dep. Khartoum Tuesdays. div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:

From December 2nd until further notice the "Train de Luxe" composed exclusively of Sleeping and Restaurant Cars will every once Wednesday and Saturday at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor every Thursday and Sunday at the same hour. The Sleepers and Dining Cars will no longer be attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo and 5.30 p.m. from Luxor respectively.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
London Correspondent's Offices -36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices -No. 1 Sharia Zervudachi, (opposite Agricultural Bank.
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1906.

div.head: ARMY REFORM
div.p: What Mr. Halane will do at the War Office lies in the womb of the future, but if we are to believe his own utterances we know what he will not do. He has assured us very emphatically that he means to keep Army administration quite outside party politics, and hopes to place its efficiency before all questions of economy and finace. Thee are brave words, rather suggestive of the novice who has never yet benn under the Treasury lash, and we may recall them some day when he has been compelled to prune down his too ambitious estimate to meet the requirements of some cheese-paring Budget. Another promise will be more easily kept. Mr Haldane should have no difficulty in maintain pleasant relations with his military colleagues. the expert memmbers of the Army concil, and will avoid friction cause by differeces of opinon and want of personal sympathy which certainly porevailed often during the late regime. The new secaratary of state has the advantage of an affable and concililiatory manner, and he has begun well by a franl admission of his ignoreance of army affairs and his willingnedd to be guided by those who are better informed. The chief fault in Mr. Arnold-Forster was that he knew everything better than anyone else. He was, moreover tied and bound by the previously-expressed views on some of the most intricate points in a business of the most extreme difficulty. Mr. Haldane tells us he has an open mind and if this attitude is lasting and permits him to accept the best that his predecessors have already given us, there may be some hope of a settlement of matter still in a fluid condition.

We hear much of the provision of a national army as the chief aim to be helf in view by our new War Office administrator, and no one will question its paramount importance. The phrase is mere bombastunless it is analysed and an exact definition arrived at. The commom idea is that defence of Great Britain is the principal raison detre of a national army. Many people discount this on the faith or rather hasty conclusions that invasion is out of the question. We leave this consideration aside, convinced that our real and more pressing needs lie beyond the four seas- needs at the remote extremities of our far-flung frontier line, and no doubt for the moment in abeyance. Yet our army exsits primarily for foreign service, for the current police duties of the Empire and to meet the larger and more desperate emergencies that may some day arise. To prepare for them acequately is the true role of the far-seeing War Minister, and the best, the only effective, means is the constitution of an enormus reserve of stored up strength available for prompt mobilisation in the hour of trial. The auxiliary forces can never be utilised on their present footing, and we know now that the sugguested organization of a home service army will not work on the lines proposed by Mr. Arnold-Forester. The necessary personnel are not forthcoming; the men will not join the newly devised regiments, for some unexplained reason another instance of the caprices of voluntary enlistment. The problem remains to be solved by Mr. Haldane, if indeed, he touches it at all unless it is forced upon him.

He has a full programme and has many urgent needs on his card. The question of recruiting is, as ever, of the first importance, and likely to become accentuated should the party now in power be beguiled into coqueting with Home Rule. It has been pointed out that with an independent Parliament in Dublin the British Army would look in vain for Irish recruits, hitherto so valuable an addition to the forces of the crown. Apart from their soldierly qualities, the loss in numbers would be felt seriously. Mr. Haldane has declared himself, as might have been expected, the determined opponent of any form of conscription. What if it is forced upon him as the direct result of making Irishmen foreigness? Let us hope that the notion is far-fetched and that the evil consequences of Home Rule in this regard may be averted. A more pressing requirement today is to find officers for all branches of the service and more particularly the auxiliary forces, where the dearth constantly increases. Neither the Militia nor the Volunteeers can take their place in the national array until this defect is mended, and the remedy, except by regular payment is not easy to find. The shortage in the regulars has been in a measure dealt with by Mr. Arnold Forster, although hardly on large permanent lines. The late War Minister has to some extent smoothed his successor's path by carrying out the rearmament of the field artillery and the introduction of the new infantry rifle, but his legacy of the great General Staff is a more doubtful asset not readily or easily realisable.

div.head: CUT OUT HER TONGUE - A FANATIC WOMAN'S ATTEMPT TO WORK A MIRACLE
div.p: According to the "Straits Times" a procession of Hindus took place recently in Singapore, the men being under hypnotic influence and with barbs of iron and wood sticking in their flesh. Interest in the procession centred in a woman, known for her great piety. She joined in the procession with a brass pot, containing pure water, which she hoped would turn into milk.

To her disappointment and dismay she found on uncovering the pot at her destination that the water was unchanged. Not to be outdone, she tried to bring about another miracle. Seizing a knife which she carried, she cut off her tongue about an inch from the end and laid it on a leaf in front of her. With blood dripping from her mouth, she knelt before this bit of tongue, praying and waiting for what remained of it in her mouth to grow to its original length. The temple was filled with spectators, who remianed till a late hour to see miracle number two brought off.

The woman waited till a little past midnight, most of the time in a kneeling posture, but the tongue would not grow. The temple authorities advised her to return home, as they declared her not "good enough for miracles."

div.head: Local and General
div.p:
Zizinia Theatre.
A special performance of Cyrano de Bergerac will be given to morrow evening in aid of the Soci^to Internationale de* Employes d’Alex-andrie. Austro-Hungarian Ball.
The ball of the Cairo Austro-Hungarian Benevolent Society, or der the patronage of Cpnnt K^brodski, will b9 given on the 23rd inst. at the Savoy Hotel. Regimental Sports.
The regimental sports of the Royal InniskU-ling FaRiliers will be held on Satarday, 10th inst. The invitations previously issued hold good for this date. Alexandria Blind School.
Mrs. Moss ai d Mrs. Carver have very kindly given the boys of the Blind School a treat for the New Year and have also contributed towards the funds of the institution. Death in the Bath.
A native porter was yesterday taking a bath iu his master’s house in the Attarin quarter when he was suffocatoi inside the bath by tli9 fumes of the oharooal. OUR SPECIAL CABLES. ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
OPTIMISTIC OUTLOOK PREVALENT. ( Gazette's Special Service. )
London, Tuesday.
A very firm tone prevails owing to the important announcement of Count Cassini, the Russian delegate at the Algeoiras Conference, who has described his views as to the outcome of the Conference’s proceedings as being more than optimistic.
The Herman official and semi-rffioial press is also giving vent to satisfactory assurances of a pacific solution to the Morocco question. DUCAL ENGAGEMENT. Alhambra Theatre.
During the last few days of the French operetta company’s stay, until the 11th inst., the prices of admission will be reduced to P.T. ^0 and P.T. 5, boxes being P.T. 60.
Walker and Meimarachi.
The subscription list for the new issue of shares opens to-morrow and closes on the 9th inst. Anplications must be addressed to the Anglo-Egyptian Bank.Limited.at Cairo or Alexandria. [Advt.] ( Gazette's Special Service. )
London. Tuesday.
The engagement is announced of the wealthiest heiress in Great Britain, Lady Mary Hamilton, daughter of the 12th Duke' of Hamilton and Brandon, to the Marquis of Graham, heir to the dukedom of Montrose . THE UNIONIST SPLIT. Murder.
The Greek rayah who was stabbed with a knife by a waiter of Greek origin at Rarmoas on the 29th ult., succumbed to his injuries yesterday. The murderer, who confessed his crime, is in prisoD. ( Gazette's Special Service )
London, Tuesday.
The Rt. Hod. Walter Long, who was pointed out as a possible leader to tha distracted Unionist Party, has declared formally that he has no intention whatsoever of taking the leadership. Cotton in Turkey.
The Sublime Ottoman Porte has decided to purchase a large quantity of Egyptian cotton Reed in order to distribute it among the farmers throughout the Empire so that the cotton m*y be improved. THE TURNER TREASURE TROVE. Pleasure Cruises.
Among the liners dae at Alexandria this month on pleasure cruises are the S S. Orient, of the Orient-Pacific Line, which arrives on the 23rd inst for a four days’ stay, and the Hamburg-America's 8.8. Moltke, dae at Alexandria on the 27th inst. Prince and Nazli's Statements.
rThe declaration of Prinoass Nazli as to the Egyptians being only babies politically still smonlders in the Columns of the vernacular Pres$>^‘Al Express” condones her Highness’s remark on the ground thit she ia not of Egyptian but of Turkish origin. British Chamber of Commerce.
The annual general meeting pf members of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt will be held to-morrow (Wednesday) at. 4 p m., in Messrs. Carver Bros. and Company’s office0,Old Boarse-street, Alexandria, to receive the committee’s report and accounts for the year 19 >5, and to el set four me chars to the committee for 1906. ( Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Tuesday.
Extraordinary interest is being manifested in the wonderfol discovery of forgotten masterpieces of Tamer. Huge crowds flocked to see these pictures yesterday. KHEDIYIAL LEVEE. A Musical Event,
Signor Arrgo Serato’s third concert is advertised to taka place at fhs Continental Hotel on Wednesday, 7th inst.., at 5 15 p.m., when he will be accompanied as nsnal by that gifted pianiste, Mme.Malatesta.The programme holds many items, including a sonata of Saint-Saens and a polonaise of Vieaxtempa, and Mme Malltesta will contribute as her solos a toccata by Chaminada and also one of Liszt’s rhapsodies.
To Help Young Girlc,
On January 19, 1906, a branch of the “Union Internationale des Amies de la jenne fills” was opened in Alexandria. The headquarters of the .society is at Nenohatel. The chief object of this society i* the protection of young Buropaan girls living in this omutrv aw*y from relations and frieods of whatever creed or nationality Tin folio ving ladies hav* baen named as a committee M ue. de Planta, president ; Mr*. 8. H. Carver, vice-president; Mme. H. D. Tsykaias, Inn. *e\; Miss E Thomas, assist, treisurer; Mme. Q Schn'er, Mme* Fred. Ott, Mm*. F. Simoudand Mme. Mataras/ Thar; committee propose to found an International Home in Alexandria. This will be opened very shortly as the need of it is more and more felt. A. house has been taken and th« neuemry arrangements will be mtde in the next fow day^,
Scarabs,
A new work by Mr. Percy E. Newberry has oeeri issued on the scarab, or beetle-shaped seal which is one of the commonest of Egyptian objects. div.head: TODAY"S TELEGRAMS- THE UNIONIST PARTY
div.p:
BALFOUR v. CHAMBERLAIN.
QUESTION OF THE LEADERSHIP.
London, February 5.
The Unionist party will meet next week in order to consider the position.
The ‘Time says that Mr. Chamberlain desires to make the tariff reform paramount in thepolioy of the Unionists. It is understood l that Mr. Balfour will not assent, considering it inexpedient in view of the result of the elections. If Mr. Balfour adheres to this standpoint, Mr. Chamberlain, who is personally unwilling to take the leadership, will propose a third person, probably Mr, Long, to lead the party. Mr. Balfour deolines to acquiesce an 1 considers it highly inadvisable to exclude from the party the Unionists who do not oonour in tbe Chamberlaini te fiscal policy.
The Unionist newspapers are divided on the leadership of the party. The “Standard,” the "Morning Post,” and the "Globe’^are strongly Chamberlainite. Others uphold Mr. Balfour, The "Times” strongly deprecates any widening of the cleavage and considers^that in the present situation the Unionist party has no nee 1 to formulate a vary definite policy. It is noteworthy that the personal relations between Mr. Balfour and Mr. Chamberlain are most friendly. (Reuter)

div.head: THE ENTENTE CORDIALE
div.p:
L.C.C. MEMBERS IN PARIS.
Paris, February 5.
The members of the London County Council have met with a magnificent reception here. They were entertained at a banquet in th * H6tel de Ville, at which the most oordii speeches were exchanged. (Renter;
Paris, February 5.
A hundred of the members of the London County Council have arrived here and have been oheered by the populace. In the evening there was a banquet in their honour at the Hotel de Ville. Messrs. Brousse, Selves, Bertel and Cornwall toasted the Entente Cordiale.
(Havat)
